utterances: All this week, we've been hearing about immigration.
And this morning, we have a scene of the country from which millions of immigrants come.
Nearly 50 percent of the people who live in Mexico live in poverty, and some people make a living at a garbage dump in Mexico City.
NPR's Lourdes Garcia Navarro profiles a man of God who has been helping those people for more than 20 years.
This vast wasteland on the edge of Mexico City is a place where humans serve the same purpose as bacteria.
Mounds of refuse, that fester in this eight-mile long garbage lot, are picked through by the dump dwellers.
Items that can be recycled are sold for a pittance.
People work 12 hours to make 30 pesos, about two and a half-dollars.
Some a hundred families actually reside here in shacks made of salvaged cardboard and tin, amidst the wild dog's stink and filth.
It's a life of despair and wretched poverty.

Sometimes we don't even make enough money to afford a few beans.

It's horrible here, really horrible.
But we have no other option.
We can't find work easily.
Anastacio Tavillia has been living here in this marginal society for 24 years.
He has no family.
He can barely read or write.
(Through Translator) The government doesn't pay any attention to us at all.
We are like lost people to them.
Actually, we are like garbage to them.

The cross is made of found objects from the dump, a gift from the people here to Father Roberto Givara(ph).
